Sol, Draven, and Jhin probably in that order. 

The first two are obvious. But Jhin is so egotistical he sees everyone around him as objects to be murdered for his art, which in itself is just an extension of his ego. In truth he's just a petty thug, but he fails to see himself as anything but an artistic genius. And if he has anything brought to shatter that view of his own genius he excuses it in a way to make him appear more important than he is. If people don't like getting murdered? They are too dull to understand his genius. People are sent to capture him? Well all great artists are not understood in their time and he of course is a great artist.

I agree with most of this, but Jhin isn't a petty thug.  He actually puts real thought into his "art," to the point where a normal man saw the corpse of someone he had killed, and the way the person was cut up was so horrific that the guy who saw it went mad on the spot (He considers that a positive review).  Even though he's undoubtedly a dangerous psychopath and one of the most evil characters I've ever read about, he is still an "artist" who conducts himself with style.  And like I said, he considers someone going completely mad at seeing his "art" a good thing.

But I digress.  With how he is now and that his current condition grew less from personal ego, more for a lust of freedom which was acquired through power, and the fact he actually showed a tinge of regret for having to finish the process (because I'm going to assume that at the point it was at, if he didn't continue, he'd die with everyone else), I would say his egotistical phrasing developed from him needing to validate his reason for being the way he is.

Draven doesn't need to validate his "awesomeness" to himself.  He just wants others to know how great of a Draven that he thinks he is.

Aurelion Sol is at an existential level that the only reason he talks to us the way he does is because we're a bunch of random cats, dogs, raccoons, etc. that can audibly communicate in a language he understands. (I can equate us to insects, honestly. It's the same deal)


So, yeah.  If it's not for the self-imposed ego, I think Xerath would be a rather depressed man.
